message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of severe headache followed by neck stiffness and nuchal rigidity are consistent with a subarachnoid hemorrhage, and a non-contrast CT scan of the head may not always be sensitive enough to detect it. A lumbar puncture should be done to evaluate for the presence of blood in the CSF, which is diagnostic of subarachnoid hemorrhage. IV tPA is not indicated in this case as there is no evidence of acute ischemic stroke. Diffusion-weighted MRI is not a urgent diagnostic test for this presentation. Placement of a VP shunt is not indicated as there is no evidence of hydrocephalus at this time.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms of sudden-onset severe headache, neck pain and stiffness, and nuchal rigidity suggest a subarachnoid hemorrhage. A noncontrast CT scan of the head is normal, but lumbar puncture should be performed to confirm the diagnosis by identifying blood in the cerebrospinal fluid. IV tPA is used to treat ischemic strokes, not hemorrhagic strokes. Diffusion-weighted magnetic resonance imaging is useful in detecting acute ischemic stroke, not subarachnoid hemorrhage. Placement of a VP shunt is used to treat hydrocephalus, not subarachnoid hemorrhage.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s sudden onset severe headache, neck pain and stiffness, nuchal rigidity, and recent history of trouble putting weight on her right leg suggest subarachnoid hemorrhage. CT scan may not show a hemorrhage in the early stages, so the next best step is to perform a lumbar puncture to evaluate for the presence of blood in the cerebrospinal fluid. IV tPA is used for acute ischemic stroke, not subarachnoid hemorrhage. Diffusion-weighted magnetic resonance imaging of the brain is not the first-line diagnostic test for subarachnoid hemorrhage. Placement of a ventriculoperitoneal shunt may be indicated after the acute hemorrhage has been treated.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden-onset severe headache and nuchal rigidity suggest a subarachnoid hemorrhage, and the negative CT scan does not exclude it. Therefore, the next best step in management would be a lumbar puncture to assess for xanthochromia, which would confirm the presence of blood in the cerebrospinal fluid. IV tPA is used for ischemic strokes, which is not the case here. Diffusion-weighted magnetic resonance imaging and VP shunt are not appropriate management strategies for subarachnoid hemorrhage.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). While a CT scan can detect SAH, it may not be visible in the early stages, and a lumbar puncture is more sensitive. IV tPA is used for acute ischemic stroke, which is not the case here. Diffusion-weighted magnetic resonance imaging is not the first-line investigation for SAH. Placement of a VP shunt is used for hydrocephalus, which is not currently indicated. Therefore, the next best step in management is a lumbar puncture.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of severe headache and neck stiffness suggests subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH), and the previous episode of leg weakness suggests a possible transient ischemic attack (TIA) or stroke. A normal CT scan does not rule out SAH, so a lumbar puncture is needed to confirm the diagnosis. IV tPA is used to treat ischemic stroke, not SAH. Diffusion-weighted magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is useful in evaluating for stroke but not SAH, and a ventriculoperitoneal shunt would be used to treat hydrocephalus, which is not indicated in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of a thunderclap headache, nausea, vomiting, neck pain and stiffness, and significant nuchal rigidity suggest a subarachnoid hemorrhage. A normal CT scan does not exclude a subarachnoid hemorrhage, and a lumbar puncture is necessary to confirm the diagnosis. IV tPA is not indicated as the patient does not meet criteria for acute ischemic stroke. Diffusion-weighted MRI and VP shunt placement are not indicated in this scenario.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of headache, neck pain and stiffness, and nuchal rigidity suggest a possible subarachnoid hemorrhage. A noncontrast CT scan of the head is normal, which can occur in 10% to 15% of cases of subarachnoid hemorrhage. Lumbar puncture is the next best step in the management of this patient, as it will confirm the diagnosis by detecting blood in the cerebrospinal fluid. IV tPA is not indicated as there is no evidence of ischemic stroke. Diffusion-weighted magnetic resonance imaging of the brain is not likely to change the management of this patient in the acute setting. Placement of a VP shunt is not indicated at this time.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of severe headache and neck pain suggests subarachnoid hemorrhage, and the nuchal rigidity confirms it. The normal CT scan of the head does not rule out subarachnoid hemorrhage, so a lumbar puncture is the next best step to confirm the diagnosis. Options A and D are not appropriate as they are not indicated in the management of subarachnoid hemorrhage. Option C may be useful later in the management of the patient, but obtaining a definitive diagnosis with a lumbar puncture is the priority at this time.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden-onset severe headache, neck pain and stiffness, nausea and vomiting, along with nuchal rigidity suggests the possibility of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). However, the noncontrast CT scan of the head is normal, making it necessary to perform a lumbar puncture to confirm a diagnosis of SAH. IV tPA is used for ischemic strokes, not hemorrhagic strokes. Diffusion-weighted magnetic resonance imaging of the brain may be helpful in determining the cause of the patient’s symptoms, but a lumbar puncture is more urgent. Placement of a ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt would not be appropriate at this time as the patient does not have hydrocephalus.
